gun waved their arms and beat the horses to make them turn and move on. The horses moved off the bank. The ice, that had held under those on foot, collapsed in a great mass, and some forty men who were on it dashed, some forward and some back, drowning one another. 
Still the cannon balls continued regularly to whistle and flop onto the ice and into the wa- ter and oftenest of all among the crowd that covered the dam, the pond, and the bank.
